content: so you made yourself set of sweet dungeon tiles you put them on your table
at your last game and everybody loved it but you want to enhance the look a
little bit further as you may have guessed I'm not a fan of having walls on
my tiles they impede visibility they can get in the way while you're trying to
play and honestly they're not that necessary but that doesn't mean that I
don't love some 3d elements popping up off the tiles to give things some more
dynamics so you got a room and you want some pillars for your players or
monsters or whatever to be able to hide behind to knock over you know players
come up with all sorts of things to do with objects in the room but I'm going
to show you how you can make these which look really really good very detailed
and I'm telling you require basically no skill and like no cost did you require
some patience and a bit of time but if you're willing to put in the time you
can have a set of these fantastic looking pillars for your table so gather
your materials sit down at your crafting table and let's build you'll need some
foam board specifically I use the ready board brand from Dollar Tree as you can
easily peel the paper off if you're not familiar with the product
check out DM Scotty's video explaining it once you've peeled off the paper from
both sides cut several 1-inch strips the amount you will need will depend on how
many pillars you plan to make but as a guideline each pillar will need 15
lineal inches of foam next cut these strips into 1-inch squares you don't
need to be incredibly precise with this as some slight variance in size will
actually enhance the look later I just use the 1-inch squares on my cutting mat
as a guide as it's faster than measuring now grab a nail file and use it to
slightly bevel the edges of each square make sure to do this on both sides two
or three light passes on each edge should be more than enough now
carve the bricks use the edge of your file to cut a groove on the sides of
your squares do this about two-thirds in from the corners and always keep the
grooves on the same corner it should create a pattern that looks
something like this once you have a whole bunch of these
squares ready you can start assembling when you stack these it's important to
flip every second one so you never end up with two grooves directly above each
other once assembled a realistic brick pattern will appear the fastest and
easiest way to assemble these pillars is with hot glue
I made my pillars 14 squares hi once your pillars are assembled use some
tinfoil to give them some stone texture for the bases cut some more foam board
into one and a half inch squares to give the pillar some weight I use one-inch
washers trace out the washer onto the bases and carefully cut out that area
cut some cardstock squares slightly smaller than the bases and glue them to
the bottom of the foam board this will hold the washer in place
now glue your washers into the bases I decided to use too as I wanted these to
have a nice amount of weight but you can get away with using just one and bevel
the edges of the bases and add some brick lines just like your other pieces
then just hot glue your pillars to their bases to finish the tops I added one
more square as a cap but this one doesn't have the brick lines carved in
you may end up with some of your washer showing through on the base to hide that
as well as blend the seam from the base to the pillar you can use some sort of
compound as a filler I usually use drywall joint compound but you could use
an acrylic caulking or even just some glue I press a small amount of filler
into the seam and then use a wet paint brush to blend it to really stiffen up
the foam and the seams I give everything a coat of Mod Podge you can do this with
watered-down PVA glue but I find that for some reason the consistency of Mod
Podge allows it to apply a little more easily to dress up a couple of the
pillars I glue some rubble to the bases I'm using a decorative broken glass from
Ikea as I like the shape of the pieces for rubble you can use coarse sand rocks
bits of styrofoam really anything you have on hand for added strength instead
of just base coating these pieces with black paint you can give them another
coat of Mod Podge but with some black paint mixed into it this is also a great
way to ensure full coverage if you're planning on giving these a coat of spray
paint once the black code has fully dried you
can give everything a heavy dry brush with dark gray you're basically looking
for full coverage while leaving the cracks black you can make your brick
look a little more interesting by individually painting a selection of
bricks with some contrasting colors I did some with sort of a reddish brown
and some in a medium tan the trick here is not to overdo it just do several in
each color trying to keep it looking somewhat random now to highlight the
stone texture use a lighter grey to sparingly dry brush the surface go very
lightly at first with minimal paint until you feel comfortable with the
effect complete the paint job with a black wash a cover how to make your own
black wash for very cheap in episode 12 when the black wash has dried you can
add one more layer of protection with a coat of Minamata satin polyurethane as
described in episode 10 with all the Mod Podge these pieces probably don't
require it but I personally like the slight wet look at Gibbs alright guys I
hope you found this video helpful if you did please smash that like button leave
a comment below and of course hit that subscribe button if you haven't already
you can also find a link in the description below to the black magic
craft Facebook page there I post pictures of all sorts of stuff that I'm
working on stuff that doesn't make it to videos it's also a place that you can
send me photos of your own black magic craft builds alright until next time
peace
